misconceptions.inferred_category_name: No issue / Correct parallel-array sorting model
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that if you swap the score elements during sorting, you must also swap the corresponding name elements to keep each name aligned with its score, and that after sorting ascending the last element holds the maximum score.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: No conceptual gap detected here: in Java, arrays store values by index; swapping both arrays at the same indices preserves the name-score pairing. After an ascending sort, index N-1 indeed contains the highest score (and its paired name).
misconceptions.error_manifestation: No error; produces correct output (assuming N > 0 and valid inputs).

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student assumes there is always at least one student, so accessing index N-1 is always safe.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, arrays are 0-indexed and accessing index -1 (when N==0) throws an ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException. If the problem statement doesn’t guarantee N>=1, the program should guard against N==0 before reading topName/topScore.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Runtime exception when N == 0 (ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException) at names[N-1] / scores_array[N-1].

evidence.code_snippet:
String topName = names[N - 1];
int topScore = scores_array[N - 1];
